original_comment:
Looking at the graph, I can see that, for legacy applicants, applications of those with a family income rank of more than the 50th percentile essentially stays at a rate of 2.5 times as likely or more to be accepted. Legacies aren't necessarily considered to be disadvantaged, but non-legacies may be, so it'll be interesting to see if legacy admissions rise or drop.

A headline that captures the graph's main idea might be "Application Distortion: Legacies vs. Everyone Else."

original_comment:
I notice that there is an obvious correlation between parents’ income and the likelihood of getting into an Ivy League. Also, when your parents or another close relative went to that college, the chances of getting accepted are about doubled for every income level. Additionally, I notice a subtle increase in acceptance rates at the low end of the income spectrum, presumably because of financial aid.

I wonder why the Ivy League college system is like this; your chances of getting in are significantly larger if you’re extremely wealthy. I think it’s because the colleges like to have rich people attending their schools and the rich surely pay them a large amount of under-the-table money to get their sub-par children into such renowned schools. I think when so-called “elites” attend the Ivy Leagues, colleges then have the self-adorned right to raise tuition and make their school more prestigious.

This relates to me because I am a high school junior looking to go to a good college and I am curious about acceptance rates vs. income and other factors, such as the legacy status. My entire community is mostly just my school and a small town, so I suppose many of the people in my community (at least those whom I regularly interact with) would be concerned about similar issues within the elite college community.

Catchy headline: Ive League Colleges: Wealthy in Knowledge or Wealthy in Reputation? Discover the astonishing magnitude of “elite” colleges’ lust for money and power

I notice the systemic barriers which keep the rich able to obtain a good education. Those systemic barriers being the legacy boost during college admissions- especially to top selective universities. This graph is appalling by the means which it keeps the less fortunate less fortunate; and, the rich richer via generational wealth and nepotism. 

What do you wonder?
I wonder why these colleges still implement legacy boosts during the college admissions process. I wonder what benefit do these universities get by preferring legacy students? Also, how does legacy boost- in addition to affirmative action- completely deplete the middle class’ chance of attending an elite university?

How does this relate to you and your community?
Residing in a rural area I and my fellow peers would most likely be unable to attend an elite university due to the systemic boost of legacy admits- which many legacies attend wealthy private schools. Additionally, we might also not have the different resources for the criterion of admissions at elite universities- which wealthy private schools might have readily available. 

Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
Systemic barriers captivating colleges: Legacies leading admission

original_comment:
It doesn't seem to have occurred to anyone that the most prestigious colleges are that way because of who they admit, and changing that is not going to give an advantage to those who were formerly not admitted, but will simply make these schools no longer prestigious.

That is, it is plausible that Harvard graduates are desirable because Harvard screens its applicants for desirability, not because of the education they get once they are there. It's a similar fallacy for all highly selective schools - if a school only allows in the best students (for whatever meaning of best you like), the school and it's teachers don't have to be any good, because the best students will excel regardless.

I noticed that legacy applicants had more than double the advantage of being admitted into college compared to non-legacy students. I also noticed that up until the 99.9 percentile, the graph stays kind of flat, but then it suddenly grows for both legacy and non-legacy students. original_comment:
I noticed that legacy students of all income rankings tend to see significantly higher admission rates than non legacy students. To a certain extent, income also seems to be a determining factor in admission rates. Students with family incomes ranking in the top 10% are much more likely to be admitted than those in the bottom 10%. 

The fact that students are more likely to be admitted when their family income is higher is interesting. Many colleges claim to be need-blind when looking at college applications, so the data has to be due to other factors possibly influenced by higher income. Students with more resources have easier access to information, tutors, or other outside assistance. These resources are likely to positively impact their academic performance and college applications. However, students with less resources end up disadvantaged in comparison to these students.

This graph sheds light on how a student’s family background — something they have no control over — can impact their lives. A student whose family has a higher income and more access to resources will typically end up more successful than one with a lower income. As a community, students with less access to resources needed for academic excellence need to be addressed. If we can address this issue, we can reduce the disparity between legacy and non-legacy, or high-income and low-income.
